stories.text:
I've been spinning my wheels trying to get my business off the ground for four years and really want to get back into an environment where I'm not solely responsible for pushing forward every aspect of a project (including all of the "fun" business maintenance aspects). However, for the last year I've also been taking care of a <1 year old full time and have hesitation interviewing for dev positions again because 1) there didn't feel like enough time in the day to study for interviews before.. much less now and 2) my IQ seems to have temporarily dipped from being a stay-at-home dad with all of the distractions that entails.

It's a nice fantasy that I'd be able to reject all interview processes that have either coding tests or whiteboard grilling, but my experience so far has been that the companies without that either don't exist or aren't interested in me. I'm not in a particularly hot tech hub -- although the recent uptick in indefinitely remote positions has gotten me to start looking seriously again. It's really hard to imagine I'd be competitive for these positions if I was struggling to get interviews before. (My business was initially started out of desperation and for something to do other than study for interviews).

(Edit: Part of the text was lost at some point and I can't remember all of it.)
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you deal with interviewing as a stay at home parent?
